thread.title: AT&T rebranding, ramping up wireless service in Mexico
thread.title_full: AT&T rebranding, ramping up wireless service in Mexico | Dallas Morning News

author: GARY JACOBSON
title: AT&T rebranding, ramping up wireless service in Mexico
text:
A big difference between Mexican and American consumers is the amount of plastic they carry.
In the U.S., says Thaddeus Arroyo, AT&T’s top executive in Mexico, the typical person has three or four credit cards.
In Mexico, the average is less than half a card.
“It’s a cash-based economy,” Arroyo said of Mexico. “So how we serve this country is really different.”
Dallas-based AT&T spent $4.4 billion this year to acquire two Mexican wireless companies, Iusacell and Nextel Mexico.
This week, the telecom giant began rebranding those Mexican operations.
“We’ll replace Nextel and Iusacell with AT&T over the course of the next year,” said Arroyo. By the end of 2016, he said, everything will be AT&T.
AT&T also plans to invest $3 billion or so to expand its high-speed mobile service to 100 million people in Mexico by the end of 2018.
“By the end of this year we will reach 40 million people,” Arroyo said. “By the end of next year, 75 million people.”
AT&T’s wireless move into Mexico comes amid its biggest corporate transformation yet.
It recently completed the acquisition of DirecTV, the satellite television distributor, which has substantial operations in Latin America as well as in the U.S.
In wireless, AT&T plans to create a North American mobile network that eventually reaches 400 million people in the U.S., Mexico and Canada.
Arroyo, 52, was appointed to his position in January and moved to Mexico City in February. He had been president of technology development for AT&T.
He said mobile broadband development in Mexico is at an early “pivot point.”
Smartphone penetration among mobile customers there is just 30 percent, he said, compared with 80 percent in some areas of the U.S.
One of the reasons for the difference, Arroyo said, is that most of the broadband available in Mexico is older-generation technology. Slow mobile broadband is not as useful as 4G LTE, the latest technology, which AT&T plans to deploy.
“The Internet in Mexico is just like the U.S.,” Arroyo said. “It’s becoming deeply embedded in everyone’s life.”
In a securities filing, AT&T said it had 9 million subscribers in Mexico at the end of June. For the second quarter, the company reported $491 million in revenue from its Mexican wireless operations and expenses of $654 million.
Overall revenue at the company in the quarter was $33 billion. That number will increase substantially with the integration of DirecTV.
Arroyo said his operations in Mexico employ about 16,000 now. That number is growing, he said, but he declined to be more specific.
His goals for the next year include expanding network coverage and distribution and enhancing customer experiences.
“None of this is possible without the engagement of our employees,” Arroyo said. Another of his goals is for AT&T to be considered one of the best employers in Mexico.
